ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to work in a group to develop a mobile app. It was my first time creating a github repo where multiple people contribute to the code. I learned how to develop an app with react native and aws.
Software development skills that are closer to what would be necessary in the actual work place, compared to most other CS courses.
How to plan, test, develop, and organize software projects. Since it's a team-based project course, you learn how to communicate and collaborate effectively while producing a piece of software.
working with a team on a dev project, different dev strategies used in the industry like agile method, tips on code smells, industry standards, etc
I developed key knowledge, skills, and insights into becoming a good software engineer.
Fundamentals of software engineering beyond simply a programming standpoint. Software engineering design process, real-world continuous integration, how to work with a team
Working with others on more extensive coding projects, some basic software development.
Learned a lot about real SWE + best coding practices.
Learned how to develop a web or mobile application

I got experience developing an app with other students and learned a lot about the daily work of software engineers, including a lot of the tools and methods they use to facilitate collaboration and efficiency.

This course provided a great exposure to software engineering best practices, team management and product management strategy, testing and code quality, and picking the best services for your applications.

The lectures provided me with knowledge of software development process: from an initial idea, to implementation, to testing, to user feedback.
Working on my project provided me with (more) knowledge of React, MongoDB, and JavaScript.
Strategies for working in a medium-sized group on a single software product; the Agile method and industry-standard practices; a new framework such as React
The whole course was devoted to planning and developing an application, so I learned a lot about development cycles and working as a team on a project.

I learned many best practices for software engineering. I had the opportunity to develop a semester-long software engineering project with a small group, improving my ability to project plan and remotely collaborate. I learned hard skills, like how to use Git, Github, VS Code, VS LiveShare, and React.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength is that you get to work with your friends, a weakness is that you pretty much have to learn how to use different frameworks like React Native on you own.
Weaknesses is students can get away with doing little work.

I liked project-based work and the lessons that covered more broadly different aspects of software engineering in a professional work setting. I would have appreciated more guidance on how to work on a software project in the context of a university class, which differs from a job setting.

Strengths - great practice working on a group software project, really teaches you how to get better at documentation/code sharing/etc.
Weaknesses - most things you learn in lecture are things you'd learn from an internship (agile methodology, how to work on a team, etc). Since this is an upper level course, a lot of people have had these experiences already so it may be a bit repetitive
Focused on building a product, as well as a comprehensive insight into all the steps that go into it

was not incentivized to attend lecture with the amt of work for the project, even tho lecture had lots of useful practical info. but, homeworks were very manageable and mindful on top of the project, a good resume booster if ur cs, and (if ur team is good/productive etc.) it feels rewarding to do a project
I loved how project-oriented it was. It let's students work somewhat freely in their projects.
Love the flexibility of the course, but I wish there was more guidance in terms of the stacks to use.
I think there could have been lecture content related to the various frameworks/languages/tools for app dev

Strengths: complete creative freedom to make whatever you want however you want to make it.

No weaknesses, but the course could be improved by having workshops about some common backend and fronted frameworks. Some students were not familiar with any which made it hard to collaborate.

The strengths of this course are Timos's planning and organization of lectures which induced a great learning environment. The only weakness of this course was picking the groups in the beginning which was hard to navigate and evaluate the team members one would be joining.

I think the main strength is working with a group of friends on a project you like. You truly experience what it is like to develop something as a group, and you get to learn not only "CS" aspects but also teamwork aspects.
To improve it, I'd include more instruction on frameworks earlier on (e.g. a TA session on React outside of class) and provide students with more means to form a group--I got lucky, but it could've gone bad for me.

Strength: You will come out of it with a project that is actually relatively large-scale, because you have multiple people and all semester to work on it.  You will likely learn new frameworks and get a lot of good experience for interviews and jobs.  Weaknesses: Didn't learn too much from the actual lectures unfortunately

Most computer science courses at Yale are problem set based. A course which is project-based is a welcome addition to the computer science curriculum, as it allows students to build the softer skills involved in software development, as well as build a larger, more long-lasting project instead of completing a problem set and forgetting about the work forever. The material in the lectures was interesting, but as it correlated little with the actual grade received in the class, I found it difficult to motivate myself to go to lecture.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked that there was an option to take the course asynchronously. The presentations were also recorded so it helped with schedule conflicts.
Having live lectures and recordings was helpful.
The mix of synchronous and asynchronous course activities worked well.
It was tough working in a team 100% remotely as basically the entire semesters coursework, but hopefully we never have to have a semester like this again
N/A
The class was advertised as asynchronous but there were a lot of components that required you to be in person. I would have either stuck with one or the other.
Prof antonopoulos was extremely flexible and did not expect everyone to attend the live lecture, which was greatly appreciated.
This class handled in-class presentations really well. We were always given the opportunity to record presentations in advance, to allow for team members  from Europe or Asia to participate.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, because you get to spend time with your friends while you code!
Yes, good intro to working on software in teams.
Yes! Great, fun course and a real world applicable CS elective
YES if u plan on going into SWEchill class, project is homework, and you learn valuable industry stuff in lecture
Yes, you will get to work on a software engineering project during the whole semester.
Yes. Great exposure to software engineering and actually creating an all.
Absolutely. Great class for learning real CS skills.
Yes I would recommend it if they wanted to learn about real world software engineering. The class gives you a good idea of what working in industry looks like.

Absolutely! Take this course if you like the idea of developing an app with other talented students with complete structural freedom.

I had a lot of fun in this course and didnt feel stressed out or bogged down by unnecessary assignments. Most of the work was just developing the app and completing some low-pressure but useful peer-reviewing assignments.

Prof antonopoulos was knowledgeable, approachable, kind, and flexible.

Overall, this was one of my favorite courses I ever took at Yale.
Yes! Great course that all future software engineers should take.

I definitely would recommend this course to any student interested in pursuing a career in software eng/dev. I think the lectures teach you useful concepts and working on team gives you nice practical experience.
Yes, as long as you are willing to commit to a project, can work well on a team, and want to be doing that project all semester.

This is a good course if you are motivated and have a group that is committed to building a project together. It feels like there is a disconnect between the project and the class sometimes so take that as you will.

I would recommend this to any computer science student interested in pursuing software engineering, as a way to gain experience in the actual craft of software engineering and to build related soft skills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual lecture
There was an option to watch recorded lectures asynchronously. This class was very compatible for those in different time zones.
The lecture was also recorded for asynchronous viewing.
Recorded lecture available afterwards
N/A
Presentations, live and recorded, during class.
Mainly project.
Live lectures
The classes were live but I usually watched the recording afterwards, except on presentation days and when we had a guest.
